import React, { Component } from 'react' import { CCard, CCardBody, CCardHeader, CCol, CRow, CTable, CTableBody, CTableDataCell, CTableHead, CTableHeaderCell, CTableRow, } from '@coreui/react' import { API_URL } from '../../utils/constans' import axios from 'axios' export default class list_menu extends Component { constructor(props) { super(props) this.state = { menus: [], } } componentDidMount() { const fetchData = async () => { axios .get(API_URL + `menu?limit=200`) .then((res) => { const menus = res.data this.setState({ menus }) // setLoading(false); }) .catch((error) => { console.log(error) }) } fetchData() } render() { const { menus } = this.state return ( React Table Basic example

Using the most basic table CoreUI, here's how <CTable>-based tables look in CoreUI.

No Menu Link Icon Status Action {menus && menus.map((item, index) => ( {index + 1} {item.nama_menu} {item.link} {item.icon} {item.status} # ))} ) } }
